Description: Fragment of lower parts of a pottery aryballos in the form of a squatting komast or Silenos; painted decoration representing hair on pubic region and dots on body and legs; comprised of both wheel-made and mould-made components. Fine light grey fabric.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Near parallels from Naukratis (Higgins 1954, 1667, GR 1888,0601.660), Camirus, Rhodes (British Museum GR1860,0201.47, Higgins 1954, nos 1665, 1666; Jacopi 1933, fig. 91) and from Perachora, near Corinth, dated to ca. 590BC (Payne 1940, pl.109 no.199). Previously thought to be Corinthian, now known to be of East Greek manufacture. For discussion of komast subject see Dasen (2010) and Mandel (2004, 48-9). Dasen, V. 2010, ‘Squatting comasts and sacarb-beetles’, in G.R. Tsteskhladze, A.J.N.W. Prag and A.M. Snodgrass (eds), Periplous: Papers on Classical Art and Archaeology Presented to Sir John Boardman, Oxford, 89–97. Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7. Mandel, U. 2004, ‘Ägyptische Schemata in ostgriechischer Aneignung: Figürliche salbgefässe und terrakotten des 6. Jahrhunderts V. Chr’, in H. Beck, P.C. Bol, G. Kaminski and C. Maderna (eds), Fremdheit – Eigenheit Ägypten, Griechenland und Rom Austausch und Verständnis, Städel Jahrbuch Neue Folge 19, Stuttgart, 47–71. Payne, H. 1940. 'Perachora I. The sanctuaries of Hera Akraia and Limenia: the architecture, bronzes and terracottas'. Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.031) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
